For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.

For a group $G$ and a subset $X \subset G$, the subgroup $H$ generated by $X$ is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of $G$ containing $X$. It is the unique smallest subgroup of $G$ containing $X$ and consists of all elements of the form $x_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}^{\varepsilon_{n}}$ where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ and $\varepsilon_{1}, \ldots, $\varepsilon_{n} \in \{1,-1\}$, with $n$ varying over $\mathbb{N}$.

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.

Let $R$ be a ring and $\mathfrak{a}$ an ideal in $R$. The factor ring, or residue class ring, $R / \mathfrak{a}$, is defined initially as an abelian group by viewing $\mathfrak{a}$ as a (normal) subgroup of the additive group of $R$. The elements of $R / \mathfrak{a}$ are all residue classes of type $x+\mathfrak{a}$ for $x \in R$, where addition is given by $(x+\mathfrak{a})+(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x+y)+\mathfrak{a}$ and multiplication by $(x+\mathfrak{a}) \cdot(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x \cdot y)+\mathfrak{a}$. The ring properties of $R$ carry over to $R / \mathfrak{a}$.
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.
A subring $T$ of a field $K$ is called a subfield if $T$ is a field itself.

For a field $K$ of characteristic $p>0$, the map $\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$, which respects the addition on $K$, defines a homomorphism of fields known as the Frobenius homomorphism of $K$.

An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of a subgroup generated by a set requires the concept of a group, as it is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of a given group containing a specific subset.
The definition of a polynomial ring requires the concept of a commutative ring, as it is defined as the set of all sequences with elements in a given commutative ring.
The definition of a ring isomorphism requires the concept of a ring, as it is defined as a bijective ring homomorphism between two rings.
The definition of a factor ring requires the concept of a ring and an ideal within that ring, as it is defined as the set of residue classes of the ring modulo the ideal.

The definition of an irreducible polynomial requires the concept of a polynomial ring, as it is defined as a polynomial that cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials within that ring.
The definition of a subfield requires the concept of a field, as it is defined as a subring of a field that is itself a field.
The definition of the Frobenius homomorphism requires the concept of a field, as it is defined as a homomorphism of fields in characteristic p > 0.
The definition of an extension field requires the concept of a field, as it is defined as a field extension of a given field.
The definition of a solvable group requires the concept of a group, as it is defined as a group with a specific chain of subgroups where each quotient is abelian.
The definition of a p-group requires the concept of a group, as it is defined as a group whose order is a power of a prime number.
The definition of a map/function is a fundamental concept that does not depend on any other concept in this list.
